node.plaintext:
What does the fission of uranium produce?

> A uranium-235 atom absorbs a neutron and fissions into two new atoms (fission 
fragments), releasing three new neutrons and some binding energy. – Nuclear
Fission, Wikipedia [https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fission]
So welcome to FISSION Fragments #1  - our weekly links roundup. Want to get them
delivered straight to your inbox? Subscribe! We also tend to tweet a lot of
these links from our Twitter account @fissioncodes
[https://twitter.com/FISSIONCodes]  if you want to get them in real time.

We cover a lot of ground, from open source communities, licensing and ideology,
company & culture building, and of course lots around building and designing
software, new projects, and decentralized web tech of all kinds.

FISSION Fragments #1
How Opera is Using ENS to Decentralize the Web
[https://medium.com/the-ethereum-name-service/how-opera-is-using-ens-to-decentralize-the-web-ens-integration-spotlight-a545f7825724]
: "if you enter an .eth  name that has an IPFS [https://ipfs.io/]  hash in its 
ENS records
[https://medium.com/the-ethereum-name-service/the-new-ens-manager-now-supports-eip1577-contenthash-82e2d6724fae]
, the IPFS content will be displayed as a normal website." Android only for now.
The Crypto Wallet you can enable in desktop Opera also needs an Android app
[https://help.opera.com/en/how-to-use-operas-crypto-wallet-on-your-computer/].

June 27-30 is Barcelona IPFS camp [https://camp.ipfs.io/]: "A 3 day hacker
retreat designed for the builders of the distributed web". This is the place to
be if you're hacking on core IPFS.Local-first software
[https://www.inkandswitch.com/local-first.html]: Excellent long essay from Ink
and Switch that are the results of research and development over several years,
including a survey of "existing approaches to data storage and sharing". We're
not quite as radical about local-first, but we are definitely aligned around the
ideals for software and data they describe:

> In this article we propose “local-first software”: a set of principles for
software that enables both collaboration and  ownership for users. Local-first
ideals include the ability to work offline and collaborate across multiple
devices, while also improving the security, privacy, long-term preservation, and
user control of data.
Via @infominer33 [https://twitter.com/infominer33], Project Pages
[https://github.com/projectpages/project-pages], a Jekyll Template geared
towards collaborative science, with support for Matlab, Jupyter Notebooks, and
other charting, graphing, and data visualization tools. Thanks ⧉infominer  for
being such a great contributor of links to the FISSION Discord server
[https://fission.codes/discord]!

We're exploring a lot of topics around data portability and data ethics (and
also the right wording to describe these things!) The Fair Data Society
[https://fairdatasociety.org/]  and their principles
[https://docs.google.com/document/d/14-DM3M-cNCrq2Cn_7J8rRawhaoHOhlyXRPSQZ2thiuc/edit#heading=h.tyu66tcq1j2m] 
 are good reading on these topics. "Resistance is Never Futile" indeed!Via Mike Davidson @mikeindustries
[https://twitter.com/mikeindustries/status/1130688769625952256], a post from
Derrick Reimer
[https://www.derrickreimer.com/essays/2019/05/17/im-walking-away-from-the-product-i-spent-a-year-building.html] 
 that happens to mention that Stripe uses Slack but intentionally deletes
messages:

> An engineer at Stripe told me about their careful balance of email, forums, and
Slack. They recognize that Slack is not suitable for meaningful conversations,
so they automatically delete chat messages older than a few weeks to discourage
relying on it for long-term archival. In retrospectives, team members often
reflect on whether they chose the right medium (email, chat, or forum) for
various conversations.
Oyetoke Toby @OyetokeT [https://twitter.com/OyetokeT]  writes up forking
Codesandbox so you can deploy to Heroku
[https://dev.to/oyetoket/how-i-deployed-codesandbox-apps-to-heroku-ndo]. This
theme, of being able to code and deploy from anywhere, is another one we're
following closely. The article is posted to DevTo [https://dev.to], which is a
developer community we're really enjoying. You can find FISSION on there
[https://dev.to/fission], too.

Trent was at the ETHNewYork Ethereum hackathon and found a bunch of IPFS
projects [https://blog.fission.codes/fission-ethnewyork/]. We're going to be
kicking off interviews of people building apps like these.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Photo by Qingbao Meng
[https://unsplash.com/photos/01_igFr7hd4?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText] 
 on Unsplash
[https://unsplash.com/search/photos/nature?utm_source=unsplash&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=creditCopyText]
node.html:
What does the fission of uranium produce?

A uranium-235 atom absorbs a neutron and fissions into two new atoms (fission fragments), releasing three new neutrons and some binding energy. – Nuclear Fission, Wikipedia

So welcome to FISSION Fragments #1 - our weekly links roundup. Want to get them delivered straight to your inbox? Subscribe! We also tend to tweet a lot of these links from our Twitter account @fissioncodes if you want to get them in real time.

We cover a lot of ground, from open source communities, licensing and ideology, company & culture building, and of course lots around building and designing software, new projects, and decentralized web tech of all kinds.

FISSION Fragments #1

How Opera is Using ENS to Decentralize the Web: "if you enter an .eth name that has an IPFS hash in its ENS records, the IPFS content will be displayed as a normal website." Android only for now. The Crypto Wallet you can enable in desktop Opera also needs an Android app.

Local-first software: Excellent long essay from Ink and Switch that are the results of research and development over several years, including a survey of "existing approaches to data storage and sharing". We're not quite as radical about local-first, but we are definitely aligned around the ideals for software and data they describe:

In this article we propose “local-first software”: a set of principles for software that enables both collaboration and ownership for users. Local-first ideals include the ability to work offline and collaborate across multiple devices, while also improving the security, privacy, long-term preservation, and user control of data.

Via @infominer33, Project Pages, a Jekyll Template geared towards collaborative science, with support for Matlab, Jupyter Notebooks, and other charting, graphing, and data visualization tools. Thanks ⧉infominer for being such a great contributor of links to the FISSION Discord server!

Via Mike Davidson @mikeindustries, a post from Derrick Reimer that happens to mention that Stripe uses Slack but intentionally deletes messages:

An engineer at Stripe told me about their careful balance of email, forums, and Slack. They recognize that Slack is not suitable for meaningful conversations, so they automatically delete chat messages older than a few weeks to discourage relying on it for long-term archival. In retrospectives, team members often reflect on whether they chose the right medium (email, chat, or forum) for various conversations.

Oyetoke Toby @OyetokeT writes up forking Codesandbox so you can deploy to Heroku. This theme, of being able to code and deploy from anywhere, is another one we're following closely. The article is posted to DevTo, which is a developer community we're really enjoying. You can find FISSION on there, too.

Trent was at the ETHNewYork Ethereum hackathon and found a bunch of IPFS projects. We're going to be kicking off interviews of people building apps like these.

Photo by Qingbao Meng on Unsplash

node.title: Call for Alpha Testers
node.excerpt: Sign up to be an alpha tester for FISSION's first service: an IPFS add on for Heroku.
node.custom_excerpt: Sign up to be an alpha tester for FISSION's first service: an IPFS add on for Heroku.

node.plaintext:
We're building a Heroku add-on [https://elements.heroku.com/addons]  that makes
it easy to integrate InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) into apps you host there.

Heroku doesn't have a permanent file system, so anyone hosting there already has
to figure out how / where to store files, so we think it's a good place to
start.

We're looking for alpha testers to try out our add-on. The types of people we're
looking for fall roughly into three categories:

 1. You are a maintainer / contributor for an existing open source app and are
    interested in adding IPFS support for it (and getting it running on Heroku
    if it doesn't already)
 2.   You are a developer looking to experiment with IPFS and build a small open
    source test app on Heroku.
 3. You are less technical/not a developer but can follow instructions on
    copy/pasting a basic open source app and like trying out new things

Head on over to our Product Hunt Upcoming page at tools.fission.codes to signup
to be an alpha user » [https://tools.fission.codes]

Deploy to Heroku
For (3), the "Deploy to Heroku" button makes this pretty easy. There are a ton
of apps [https://elements.heroku.com/buttons]  that support this way of hosting
your own app:

Visit the Heroku Marketplace to browse the whole list 
https://elements.heroku.com/buttonsWe're slowly making a list of existing open
source apps that use IPFS and seeing if they'll run on Heroku, as well as
dreaming up some sample apps of our own.

Decentralized App Wishlist
We're also going to be looking for early adopter end users who are interested in
trying out IPFS powered apps.

We'll be writing more about taking your files with you in the future, and in the
mean time will keep pointing people at Ink & Switch's excellent article on
Local-first software [https://www.inkandswitch.com/local-first.html]. We're not
quite as set on the local part, but do think that IPFS is one of the ways we can
help users keep their files accessible.

Do you have some ideas of apps you'd like to see? Please fill out our
Decentralized Apps Wishlist survey »
[https://www.producthunt.com/ship/surveys/4135]
node.html:
We're building a Heroku add-on that makes it easy to integrate InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) into apps you host there.

Heroku doesn't have a permanent file system, so anyone hosting there already has to figure out how / where to store files, so we think it's a good place to start.

We're looking for alpha testers to try out our add-on. The types of people we're looking for fall roughly into three categories:

  1. You are a maintainer / contributor for an existing open source app and are interested in adding IPFS support for it (and getting it running on Heroku if it doesn't already)
  2. You are a developer looking to experiment with IPFS and build a small open source test app on Heroku.
  3. You are less technical/not a developer but can follow instructions on copy/pasting a basic open source app and like trying out new things

Head on over to our Product Hunt Upcoming page at tools.fission.codes to signup to be an alpha user »

Deploy to Heroku

For (3), the "Deploy to Heroku" button makes this pretty easy. There are a ton of apps that support this way of hosting your own app:

We're slowly making a list of existing open source apps that use IPFS and seeing if they'll run on Heroku, as well as dreaming up some sample apps of our own.

Decentralized App Wishlist

We're also going to be looking for early adopter end users who are interested in trying out IPFS powered apps.

We'll be writing more about taking your files with you in the future, and in the mean time will keep pointing people at Ink & Switch's excellent article on Local-first software. We're not quite as set on the local part, but do think that IPFS is one of the ways we can help users keep their files accessible.

Do you have some ideas of apps you'd like to see? Please fill out our Decentralized Apps Wishlist survey »

node.title: FISSION at the Seattle Ethereum meetup
node.excerpt: Brooke & Boris will be speaking at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup on May 28th. Plus: cyperpunk speakeasy drinks with xDAI Burner Wallet!

node.plaintext:
FISSION is excited to be featured at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup Tuesday, May
28th. 

Brooklyn will be presenting on IPFS and how FISSION is using it to build
“hostless” apps. The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is an incredibly powerful
new protocol that gives every piece of data its own unique address. It’s also
more immutable than the way many smart contracts work.

Boris recently wrote about the layers of Ethereum Governance
[https://blog.bmannconsulting.com/ethereum-governance/], and has a long history
of involvement with open source. He will talk about participating in the
Ethereum Community, the ETH1x roadmap, and how anyone can learn to contribute to
open source communities.

The theme is Cypherpunk Speakeasy, and there will be xDAI and Burner Wallets.
Kurt Barry, a software engineer from MakerDAO, will be giving a primer on DAI,
the crypto we will be using for payments.

Seattle Ethereum's First Cypherpunk Speakeasy!
Tuesday, May 28, 2019, 6:30 PM

Ada's Lab
425 15th Avenue E Seattle, wa

42 Ethers Attending  
 Get ready - it's Seattle's first Cypherpunk Speakeasy! We will be using burner
wallets loaded with dai to buy drinks and listen to some awesome speakers.
Haven't used a burner wallet before? Its the easiest, most user friendly
onboarding experience to using crypto. These events have been held all over the
world and we are excited to bring it to Sea...

Check out this Meetup →
[https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-Ethereum-Meetup/events/261257880/]

Sign up for the event on the Seattle Ethereum Meetup »
[https://www.meetup.com/Seattle-Ethereum-Meetup/events/261257880/]
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

CypherPunk Speakeasy
node.html:
FISSION is excited to be featured at the Seattle Ethereum Meetup Tuesday, May 28th.

Brooklyn will be presenting on IPFS and how FISSION is using it to build “hostless” apps. The InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) is an incredibly powerful new protocol that gives every piece of data its own unique address. It’s also more immutable than the way many smart contracts work.

Boris recently wrote about the layers of Ethereum Governance, and has a long history of involvement with open source. He will talk about participating in the Ethereum Community, the ETH1x roadmap, and how anyone can learn to contribute to open source communities.

The theme is Cypherpunk Speakeasy, and there will be xDAI and Burner Wallets. Kurt Barry, a software engineer from MakerDAO, will be giving a primer on DAI, the crypto we will be using for payments.

node.plaintext:
FISSION [https://fission.codes/]  recently organized the first event of a series
focused on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), titled RUN EVM: Opcode 1
[https://runevm.com]. There was a wide range of topics represented, including
sidechains, enterprise usage, and trusted computing, as well as many discussions
on how to improve and extend the EVM.

There was broad interest in collaborating on further specification and
improvements around the EVM and the "EVM Stack" of smart contract languages and
tooling. The first step in this is the proposal of a W3C Community Group
focused
on the EVM [https://www.w3.org/community/groups/proposed/#evm]  - please join us
there to continue the discussion.

Thank you from the entire FISSION team for your support and interest! If you are
interested in participating in future events please sign up on the RUN EVM
website [https://runevm.com/#about].

Sponsors
Brooke next to our awesome sponsorsThere were a number of sponsors that helped
to make RUNEVM Opcode 1 possible, including:

 * Consensys Diligence [https://consensys.net/diligence/]  & their MythX
   [https://mythx.io/]  platform
 * Trail of Bits [https://www.trailofbits.com/]
 * Runtime Verification [https://runtimeverification.com/]
 * SKALE Labs [https://skalelabs.com/]

And our community supporters: POA Network [https://skalelabs.com/], Enterprise
Ethereum Alliance [https://entethalliance.org/], Department of Decentralization
[https://decentralala.com/], and Full Node [https://www.fullnode.berlin/].

Speakers and Presentations
Thank you to all of the speakers for their excellent presentations, and for
sharing them:

 * EVM Improvements for Performance & Safety
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1TnMrexOvJ55EiTEPWjNH8Uy9qk5TdBvh], by
   Brooklyn Zelenka from FISSION
 * Mosaic, Meta-blockchains on Ethereum
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=10BjPNFIbt24SIfrax3Wlg1nvrcaTSora], by Ben
   Bollen from OST
 * Hyperledger Burrow and the Burrow EVM
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1EB9Crppl0I739BUYSC0yiYRAKUKT9Zluq6ZgIq77B1k] 
    & lightning talk EVM Problems
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1FfhzO86ekGbnCWoq6gYR9GEjGR-jijlx2s-H9YYjUVs]
   , by Sean Young from Monax
 * SlithIR, An Intermediate Representation of Solidity
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=16r25tcQ2cg2sY3-Yoq2PcblFeK81-qO6], by
   Josselin Feist from Trail of Bits
 * CANTO, Network layer Ethereum sidechain
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Du_SKifbElDR6qx4o-HhE85unWn-ISQ0ocYoV8dOVzs]
   , by Antoine Toulme, ConsenSys
 * KEVM, Jello Paper, IELE
   [https://drive.google.com/open?id=1gm18QBHaVTgXL6YgR06ooSlbEc8m8IIv], by
   Grigore Rousu, Runtime Verification


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
node.html:
FISSION recently organized the first event of a series focused on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM), titled RUN EVM: Opcode 1. There was a wide range of topics represented, including sidechains, enterprise usage, and trusted computing, as well as many discussions on how to improve and extend the EVM.

There was broad interest in collaborating on further specification and improvements around the EVM and the "EVM Stack" of smart contract languages and tooling. The first step in this is the proposal of a W3C Community Group focused on the EVM - please join us there to continue the discussion.

Thank you from the entire FISSION team for your support and interest! If you are interested in participating in future events please sign up on the RUN EVM website.

Sponsors

There were a number of sponsors that helped to make RUNEVM Opcode 1 possible, including:

  • Consensys Diligence & their MythX platform
  • Trail of Bits
  • Runtime Verification
  • SKALE Labs

And our community supporters: POA Network, Enterprise Ethereum Alliance, Department of Decentralization, and Full Node.

Speakers and Presentations

Thank you to all of the speakers for their excellent presentations, and for sharing them:

  • EVM Improvements for Performance & Safety, by Brooklyn Zelenka from FISSION
  • Mosaic, Meta-blockchains on Ethereum, by Ben Bollen from OST
  • Hyperledger Burrow and the Burrow EVM & lightning talk EVM Problems, by Sean Young from Monax
  • SlithIR, An Intermediate Representation of Solidity, by Josselin Feist from Trail of Bits
  • CANTO, Network layer Ethereum sidechain, by Antoine Toulme, ConsenSys
  • KEVM, Jello Paper, IELE, by Grigore Rousu, Runtime Verification
